Event description: Unknown causes, possibly neglect. The consequent failure of the irrigation system provoked the migration of up to 50,000 people from Yemen.
Amateur attempt to lower the dam

Event: Döda fallet/1796 Ragunda lake burst disaster
Event description: Natural dam of glacial till had canal dug through it for purposes of navigation. As the till was hard to dig, water was used to erode the channel. The canal led to the failure of the dam.
1,800 houses and 40,000 trees destroyed.

Inexperience with cold weather engineering allowed for a small leak in wall to form on March 28 and the dam to slump on April 2. The following day, on April 3, the dam failed and washed away down the Rideau River. A new dam of a different design was built atop the foundation of the original later that same year.
Failed in a heavy rain. Inquest found construction was culpably negligent.
Defective design and construction. Small leak in wall grew until new dam failed. More than 600 houses were damaged or destroyed. Lead to regulation.

Under the influence of heavy rain from late April, this soil dam collapsed on May 13. Water accumulated in Lake Iruka overflowed downstream, causing severe damage to Inuyama, Iwakura, Kasugai, Tsushima Yatomi, and to Komaki. 807 houses were destroyed, with another 11709 flooded.
Location: Inuyama, Aichi Prefecture(then Owari Province) - Japan

Event description: Lax regulations and cost cutting led to an insufficient design, which fell apart when the reservoir was full. 600 million gallons of water were released, wiping out 4 towns and making national headlines. This dam break led to increased regulation of dam construction.
Blamed on poor maintenance by owners, who lowered crest by a meter or more; court deemed it an "Act of God". Followed exceptionally heavy rainfall. 1,600 homes were destroyed.
A drunkard's negligence, shoddy construction, and corporate mismanagement killed as many as 150 after a routine flood exceeded the dam's design capacity.
Failure of a landslide dam. Authorities had been able to evacuate the valley.
In an extreme current, two 250-foot sections of the dam slid about 20m downstream intact. The town was left without electrical power for months.
Heavy flooding coupled with poor foundation quality. Workers managed to warn people downstream.
Design flaw; dam built on water springs. Four downstream dams and bridge destroyed; a fourth dam was opened and saved. Mills, homes and farms flooded. No fatalities.
Poor design, use of dynamite to remedy structural problems. Destroyed paper mill and much of the town of Austin. Replacement failed in 1942.
Construction flaws caused the dam failure.

Over-topped from flooding following heavy rains. Locally, blame was placed on Charles Hatfield who had been contracted by The City of San Diego for his efforts in rainmaking. Court cases following the dam's failure resulted in neither liabilities being passed to Mr. Hatfield nor the original payment, as both of the court's decisions ruled the event, 'an act of God'.
Location: San Diego County, California - United States

Event description: Over-topped from flooding; spillway inadequate, water rose over a meter higher than the dam and waterfalled over its surface. Dam had been raised after a similar earlier overtopping. Partial failure.
Location: San Diego County, California - United States

Event description: Heavy rains and lack of water-level controls caused the dam to give way. Private lake destroyed, resort area failed. Dam was later rebuilt in the 1960s
Location: Transylvania County, North Carolina - United States

Event description: Failed due to water infiltrating through sandstone foundation. Possibly more fatalities.
Poor construction and design, inferior materials. Lasted 40 days.

Event: Llyn Eigiau dam and Coedty reservoir
Event description: The outflow from Llyn Eigiau destroyed Coedty reservoir. Contractor blamed cost-cutting in construction. 25" of rain had fallen in preceding 5 days.
Geological instability of canyon wall.

Bad design and maintenance, with proximate cause of heavy rain. Dam failed at 1 am on 3 August 1933, with dam waters just 15 miles from the City of Denver. Warnings to the city by 4 am allowed most people to move out of the way of the flood waters.
Bad design and foundation.
Geological unstable base combined with flood.
A torrential rain struck around Horonai River area. This is the dam collapse in the wake, and according to official confirmed, the lost houses reached to 32.
Destroyed deliberately with explosive charge during testing and preparation for Operation Chastise in World War II.
Destroyed by bombing during Operation Chastise in World War II. Widespread destruction.
Destroyed by bombing during Operation Chastise in World War II. 11 factories were destroyed, 114 seriously damaged.
Heavy rain.
After heavy rain, the Heiwaike Dam collapsed, and water from the reservoir swallowed a downstream village. 80 houses ware damaged in Kameoka and the surrounding area.
Failure of Mount Ruapehu's crater lake. Natural tephra dam failed.
Under the influence of heavy rain, outburst with a Ninotani Lake Dam.

According to dam workers' testimonies, the grounds had serious structural deficiencies due to poor construction. On the night of January 9, a 150 meters long portion of the containing wall collapsed, releasing nearly 8 million cubic meters of stored water.
Geological fault possibly enhanced by explosives work during construction; initial geo-study was not thorough. Two villages were destroyed.

Impoundment of the clay slurry reservoir (storing the waste of the local brick factories) failed after heavy rains, inundating the Kurenivka neighborhood with meters of mud. An unofficial modern report claims as high as 1,500 fatalities, while official reports state 145.
Dam wall burst due to pressure of accumulated rain water. To protect the earthen dam from the flow of water, concrete blocks were used instead of steel-reinforced concrete due to a steel shortage.
Subsidence caused by over-exploitation of local oil field. 277 homes destroyed.

Strictly not a dam failure, since the dam structure did not collapse and is still standing. Filling the reservoir caused geological failure in valley wall, leading to 110 km/h landslide into the lake; water escaped in a wave over the top of dam. Valley had been incorrectly assessed as stable. Several villages completely wiped out.
More than $6 million estimated damages.
Failed in heavy rains. Another nearby dam did likewise.

Event: El Cobre New and Old Dam
Event description: Liquefaction during an earthquake released water and mining waste which traveled downstream and buried the town of El Cobre.

A tailings dam at Plakalnitsa copper mine near Vratsa failed. A total 450,000 m3 of mud and water inundated Vratsa and the nearby village of Zgorigrad, which suffered widespread damage. The official death toll is 107, but an unofficial estimate is around 500 killed.
Flash floods over-topped the dam during construction.
A tailings dam built too tall collapsed, flooding Certeju de Sus with toxic tailings.
Unstable loose constructed dam created by local coal mining company, collapsed in heavy rain. 1,121 injured, 507 houses destroyed, over 4,000 left homeless.
Flooding, dam outlets clogged with debris. 3,057 injuries, over 1,335 homes and 5,000 automobiles destroyed.

The dam failure was caused by extreme rainfall, beyond the planned design capability of the dam, dumped on China by Typhoon Nina. 11 million people lost their homes. Dam was later rebuilt between 1986 and 1993.

Geological problems including unsuitable bedrock, seismic activity and caves. USGS, said prior to completion: "Since such a flood could be anticipated, we might consider a series of strategically-placed motion-picture cameras to document the process". Water leakage eroded the earthen wall and lead to dam failure. 13,000 head of cattle died.
Heavy rainfall and flooding that over-topped the dam. Six other dams failed the same day, killing five people.
Unknown, possibly design error as dam was raised several times by owners to improve power generation.

The actual observed flow following the intense rainfall reached 16307 m³/s, thrice what the dam was designed for, resulting in its collapse. The 762 metres (2,500 ft) of left and 365 metres (1,198 ft) of right embankment of dam were collapsed. Within 20 minutes the floods of 12 to 30 ft (3.7 to 9.1 m) height inundated the low-lying areas of Morbi industrial town located 5 km below the dam.
Flooding beyond discharge and storage capacity damaged the main dam and destroyed the secondary dam in the scheme.
Outlet pipe erosion; dam under-maintained due to location.
Location: Rocky Mountain National Park - United States

Event description: Heavy flooding coupled with poor quality of the dam wall, lack of qualified staff and negligence of a warning of heavy rain in the area. On the next day, newspapers reported possibly 40 fatalities and 25 disappeared but in the coming days the count went down to 8 or 9. One year later, La Vanguardia spoke of 25.
Poor maintenance and low margin for error in design; outlet pipes failed leading to pressure on dam.
Poor maintenance, leakage, and consequent failure. Destroyed over 1600 houses and 2000 acres of paddy fields. Dam was 1400 years old, and heavy modern vehicles were driven across it.
Lightning struck power system, turbines shut down. Water rose behind dam while trying to restart. Backup power systems failed, could not raise spillway gates in time. Dam overtopped (rebuilt).

The embankment dam, built between 1958 and 1962 for the Borzești Petrochemical Plant on the Tazlău river, collapsed after record rainfall firstly overtopped the structure, followed by its breach later onwards. As the event happened in the night, 250 houses were destroyed, killing 25 people in the process.
Not strictly a dam failure as there was a detonation of pre-positioned explosives by retreating Serb Forces.
Dam failed after a heavy thunderstorm. The dam was in an unacceptable condition prior to failure. Widespread devastation and environmental damage.
Design and construction deficiencies resulted in failure in heavy icing conditions.

Problems started after two weeks of constant rain, which severely engorged soils, rivers and reservoirs. Post-flood enquiries discovered that the network of dikes and dams protecting the city was poorly maintained.
Heavy rain during construction caused failure, dam was later completed.

Heavy rains and flooding from Hurricane Mitch severely damaged the Mancotal and El Dorado Dams, over-topping their spillways and nearly destroying the dams. The Virgen Dam was destroyed but later rebuilt.

Over-steepened dam failed by sliding on weak clay foundation, releasing 4-5 million cubic metres of acidic mine tailings into the River Agrio, a tributary of the River Guadiamar, which is the main water source for the Doñana National Park, a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Caused by damage sustained during the 1999 Jiji earthquake.

Failure of a coal slurry impoundment. The water supply for over 27,000 residents was contaminated. The spill was 30 times larger than the Exxon Valdez oil spill and one of the worst environmental disasters ever in the southeastern United States
Extreme rainfall during the 2002 European floods.
2,000 individuals displaced and over 10,000 directly affected.
Heavy rains caused earthen Fuse plug dam and bank to wash away. 1,800 people evacuated. Flood caused the failure of the downstream Tourist Park Dam.
In heavy rains, floodgate held shut bay water pressure. 1,600 people evacuated.

Strictly not a dam or dike failure. The original peat soil surrounding a polder (where peat had subsided due to oxidization) was pushed away by the water in the canal. The peat became lighter than water during the 2003 drought. The real cause was new wooden piling along the canal. This new piling was water-tight and therefore the peat soil dried out. Around 1,500 residents had to be evacuated.
A small hole in the dam grew, spouted higher, and eventually led to failure. 104 buildings damaged or destroyed.
Poor maintenance. 3000 people homeless. A second failure happened 11 days after.
Sudden and extreme flooding caused by abnormally severe rain.

Computer/operator error; gauges intended to mark dam full were not respected; dam continued to fill. Minor leakages had also weakened the wall through piping. The dam of the lower reservoir withstood the onslaught of the flood.
Heavy rain and flooding. Several possible specific factors to include poor maintenance, lack of inspection and illegal modifications.
Tunnel collapse.
Heavy flooding, lack of maintenance. Approximately 500 homes were destroyed, displacing 1,000 people.
Failure in June 2008 Midwest floods; nearby highway washed out, creating a new channel which drained the lake.

Neglection of barrage and the building of barrage itself. The region however saw weak monsoon and multi-year drought preceding the barrage failuire. The flood affected over 2.3 million people in the northern part of Bihar.

Event: Kingston Fossil Plantcoal fly ash slurry spill
Event description: Failure of a fly ash slurry pond.
Heavy rain. 80 people injured, 2000 homeless.
Poor maintenance and heavy monsoon rain.

Not a dam failure, but rather the power station accident where the turbine 2 broke apart violently due to the metal fatigue caused by overlooked vibrations, flooding the turbine hall and causing the ceiling to collapse. The dam itself was unaffected, and the power station rebuilt within 5 years.
Heavy rain and snowmelt. Causes, deathtoll disputed. 300 people were injured and over 1000 evacuated from the village.
Sinkhole caused dam failure. Second failure of the dam, will be replaced.
Heavy Rain, low maintenance. Destroyed at least 5 homes. Buried Highway 97.
Heavy rain, flooding, malfunctioning spillwy and structural problems. Around 8,000 people had to be evacuated. Replacement uncertain due to lake-dredging debt.
Heavy rain, over-topped from flooding.
Failure of concrete impound wall on alumina plant tailings dam. One million cubic meters of red mud contaminated a large area; within days the mud had reached the Danube.
Failure of tailings dam at titanium mine. 300 homes had been rebuilt.

Failed after 2011 Tōhoku earthquake. Authorities state that the dam failure was caused by the earthquake, making these the first earthquake-caused dam failure fatalities since 1930, worldwide. Nearby dams damaged by same earthquake.
Failed after a period of flooding. 4000 people displaced.
Failed after a period of heavy snowmelt. A crack in the dam went unrepaired for years. Eight people killed and several communities flooded.
A gate in the diversion tunnel broke after a period of heavy rain during the reservoir's first filing. The accident killed ten workers.
Poor design aggravated by Typhoon Gaemi flood surge.
Downstream slope failure on a 90.3 m (296 ft) tall embankment dam, possibly as the reservoir was being filled. Residents evacuated upstream.

Tailings dam collapse due to negligent operation; reservoir was overfilled beyond design parameters despite repeated warnings of the danger combined with a minor dam breach a few months before and fundamental design flaws.
Tailings dam collapsed. One village destroyed, 600 people evacuated. 60 million cubic meters of iron waste slurry polluted Doce River, and the sea near the river's mouth.
A heavy rainstorm caused a section of a dam to crumble because of the weight of a pond above, which happened around 5 a.m.
Failed after several days of heavy rain. Private dam, causes unclear.
Dilapidated dam crumbled under heavy summer rains, 13 missing, 300 houses destroyed.
Saddle dam under construction collapsed during rainstorms. 6600 people homeless, 98 missing. Company denied the dam had collapsed.
Breach in the dam's spillway. 63,000 evacuated, 3 missing. 85 villages affected.
Overtopping after over 36" rainfall during landfall of Hurricane Florence.
Location: Boiling Spring Lakes, North Carolina - United States

Event description: Tailings dam suffered a catastrophic failure releasing 12 million cubic meters of tailings slurry.
Dam was breached after a major storm caused heavy rain.
Heavy rains overtopped and breached the dam.
Static liquefaction.
The failure of the Edenville Dam immediately upstream caused a large inflow into Sanford Lake, which overtopped the dam.
The Rishiganga dam was destroyed by either an avalanche or a glacier burst, leading to a large surge of water downstream that also breached the Tapovan Hydropower Plant. 145 people missing.
Structural failure.
Unknown, presumed intentional explosion.
